titleStmt.title: M111, set 3 of 3 [The Reader: Anonymity was a great possession]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections. 6 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M111 [The Reader]. Set 3 of 3. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections. 6 fols.
Two loose pages paginated 32 and 33, but not consecutive with the rest, on verso p. 32 is p. 185 of Between the Acts

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early writing
an impersonality, a generality. It gave us the ballads (ballds);
it gave us the songs. It allowed us to know nothing (notning) of the
writer; and so to concentrate upon his song. had
great privileges (privilges). He was not responsible. He was not self
conscious. He is not self conscious. He can borrow. He can
repeat. He can say what every one feels. No one (ne) tries to
stamp his own name, to discover (disover) his own experience (expereince), in his
work. He keeps at a distance from the present moment.
Anon the lyric poet repeats over and over again
that flowers fade; that death is the end (ned). He is never (nver) tired
of celebrating red roses and white breasts. The anonymous
playwright has like the singer this nameless (namless) vitality,
something drawn from the crowd in the penny seats and not yet
dead in ourselves. We can still become anonymous and forget
something that we have learnt when we read the plays to which
no one has troubled to set a name.

But at some (asome) point there comes a break when anonymity
withdraws. Does it come when the playwright has absorbed
the contribution (contrbution) of the audience; and can return to them
their own general life in individualised (indivisualised) single and separate figures?
xmxmxmxmxmmmxxmxmxmx the complete [figure?] the , the There comes a point (mpoint) when the
audience is no longer master of the playwright (palaywright). Yet he is
not separate from them. A common life still unites them;
but there are moments of separation (seapaeation). Now we say, he is
speaking (spaeking) our own thoughts (thoghts). Now thxmxmxmxmxmxmxxxx he is
our (slves). But then this sense of individuality (indivi uality) comes fitfully.
The beauty which is so frequent and astonishingly (astoinshingly)

The great house that deplored becomes
solid and entire in the pages of Lady s
diary. From childhood she was tenacious of her hereditary
rights--her father had the right to carry the Kings
sword "and so it lineally descended (descnded) to me./ All her youth
she fought, against kinsmen, husband and the king himself
for her lxmxmxx right to inherit her (he) lands in .
"... I would never (bever) part from Westmoreland (estmoreland) while I lived
upon any condition whatsoever" she told him. When the
lands and the five castles were hers, she instantly began
rebuilding; Not only the land was hers, but
diamond buttons, rubies, fur cloaks. She As if to solidify
her (he) possessions she wrote out inventories of them. Family
love is in part the [desire? drive?] (drire) to hand on her property (proprty). She sends
for her grand (gran) children in order that they may taste the
delight of possession and so refresh her own satisfaction.
[The living body is robed splendidly (slendidly) in taffetas and satins.
the dead body is sealed (seale) in lead to preserve it from decay.]
The sense of the body permeates her pages. All movements (movemnts)
become spectacular. Crowds attend her.
Six bay horses drag (darg) the coach (coah). The coach (coah) is lined with green (grreen)
cloth, and laced with green and black silk lace. She is
for ever asserting her (he) identity (idnetity). She (he) has her initials carved
even over farm hose walls. This is her property; this land
is hers by (b) right. Certain flesh and blood--
xmxmxRmxmxmx.

Some speculations on the life and person of the
Reader.

We can suppose that the reading public was brought into
existence by two causesl when the playhouse was shut down in
; and, less defintely (definietly), when the play outgrew the
theatre--when, that is, it could only be fully realised
if read. In the great age of Elizabethan literature
the reading public must have beenwas a small one , and
composed mainly of scholars and aristocrats. The lack of
general common reading is proven by the long pause,
between death and the eighteenth century,
when the plays of Shakespeare (Shakepare) hung suspended,
unrealised. They had to wait until the printed book was
held in many hands, read by many eyes in the private room
before they received the other life, the detailed the
particular (pa tciaulr) life that the reader confers Again the small
ness of the reading public and its special quality accounts
for the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism, and the general
nature of what criticism there is. It is written by writers
for writers. Both in his
and in are concerned with
the theory of writing; not with particular (partciular) instances.
They are not conscious of any curiosity on the art of the
general public. The reading public is not yet asking
for explanations, for instructions. The general public
never read the play. They had to draw in the play
as they sat or stood at the (t e) playhouse, through their

venerable institutions were being criticised (critisiced). But the public
at the and the could not feel as the public in the
19th (i9th) century (cent ry) felt when was acted that old humbugs
were being shown up; and the rottenness of society.
After all, when country squires must call in to
express their meaning, prose was not yet serviceable;
the critical spirit had no proper tool.

And in fact the dramatists were not [depicting?]
society. They were showing men & women
themselves they were
the gulf silence
So Anonymity thus lay over the

But if we cease to consider the plays separately (separetly), but
scramble (scra, ble) them together as one common attempt;
then we are able to make them serve as sketches for one
masterpiece. And the darkness in which these plays
lie helps the endeavour to conceive (conveive) of that
many nameless workers (worjers) ; and many private people
were pressing their weight were discharging their
emotion into that vast cauldron of seething matter which
at last struck out into his plays.

the horse had a green tailâ¦ What had happened to (tp) her?
When she looked out again, the flowers had vanished.

flicked on the reading lamp. The circle of
readers was lit up. There in that hollow of the sun baked
field were congregated the grass hopper, the ant, and the
beetle, rolling pebbles of baked earth through the glistening
stubble. In that rosy corner of the sun baked field,
Bartholomew, and , polished and nibbled, and broke off crumbs,

"A gentleman at has seen a in his
garden" Bartholomew announced.

The butterfly that looks like (life) a leaf? Lucy queried.
looking up from her letter.
The newspaper dropped.
"Done?" said Giles taking it from his fathers hand.

The old man relinquished his paper. He basked,
silently, in the mixed light; one hand, caressing the dog,
xixlxcx rippled folds of skin towards the collar.
The clock ticked; the house gave little cracks as if it
were very brittle, very dry. hand on the window sill
suddenly felt cold. Shadow had obliterated the garden.
Roses had withdrawn (withdarwn) fxxm for the night. Mrs Swithin,
folding her letter, leant (l ant) towards and said; "I looked
in and saw the babies; so happy; with the paper flowers on
their cots.

Giles looked up from his newspaper; Isa became a
mother again, and also a wife.
In every Elizabethan (Elizabethna) play sunk beyond recall.

If xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxm
somxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx

The life The reader then is born sometime in
the sixteenth (siteenth) century. But he is xmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxm
but his power (p wer) of influencing the playwright is very weak
in the early days. The twentieth (twentiteh) century reader
that is to say, instinctively (instinctivly) tries to adapt himself
to unfamiliar conditions in reading the earlier plays.
He tries to supply the trumpets and the flags; the citizens
and the apprentices. He substantiates (substanitates) the rather shadowy
emotion that is all he can get in the plays with a dip into
, with a dip into . He labours to supply
the sunk parts of the play; he labours to revive
the vanished cooperation between the playwright and the
audience. And he is perpetually rebuffed. He cannot
read the play into complete (comlete) being. He is therefore apt
to become not a reader but a student, a careful
collector of scattered bones. Reading is an imperfect
way of bringing the early plays into existence. It is only
fitfully that the readers faculty comes into play.
When the dramatist becomes conscious (consc ous) of the play as a work
of art; when he is able to unite the play by something
in himself-- his personality (personal ty), his style, his conception
it is then that he brings the reader into existence.

The life history of the reader from Elizabethan
times to our own is full of obscurity. At some point his
ear must have been much more acute than it is now; his sight
